description: Smallest k > 0 such that n*k is a perfect cube.
comments: Smarandache complementary cubic function.Note that in general the smallest number k(>0) such that nk is a perfect m-th power (rather obviously) = (the smallest m-th power divisible by n)/n and also (slightly less obviously) =n^(m-1)/(the number of solutions of x^m==0 mod n)^m. - _Henry Bottomley_, Mar 03 2000Multiplicative with a(p^e) = p^(2 - e%3). - _Mitch Harris_, May 17 2005
references: K. Atanassov, On the 22nd, the 23rd and 24th Smarandache Problems, Notes on Number Theory and Discrete Mathematics, Sophia, Bulgaria, Vol. 5 (1998), No. 2, 80-82.
M. Popescu, M. Nicolescu, About the Smarandache Complementary Cubic Function, Smarandache Notions Journal, Vol. 7, No. 1-2-3, 1996, 54-62.
links: Peter Kagey, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5000
K. Atanassov, On Some of Smarandache's Problems, American Research Press, 1999, 16-21.
mathematica: a[n_] := For[k = 1, True, k++, If[ Divisible[c = k^3, n], Return[c/n]]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 60}] (* _Jean-FranÃ§ois Alcover_, Sep 03 2012 *)
prog: (PARI) a(n)=my(f=factor(n));prod(i=1,#f[,1],f[i,1]^(-f[i,2]%3)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Feb 27 2013(PARI) a(n)=for(k=1,n^2,if(ispower(k*n,3),return(k)))vector(100,n,a(n)) \\ _Derek Orr_, Feb 07 2015
crossrefs: Cf. A254767 (analogous sequence with the restriction that k > n).
author: Charles T. Le (charlestle(AT)yahoo.com)
extensions: More terms from _Patrick De Geest_, Feb 15 2000
